publicwhip.spmotion: *S2M-3245# Mrs Nanette Milne: Communication Impairment—That the Parliament notes that there are an estimated 250,000 people in Scotland who have communication impairment; recognises that communication impairment can affect every waking moment of a person’s life and that those affected by communication impairment, by definition, are not easily able to speak up about their needs, and believes that the Scottish Executive should take immediate steps to support quality social action research in order to develop a comprehensive and coherent framework for action on communication impairment in Scotland.

S2M-3245# Communication Impairment (lodged on 7 September 2005) Brian Adam*, Chris Ballance*, Ms Rosemary Byrne*, Murdo Fraser*, Robin Harper*, Margaret Mitchell*, Eleanor Scott*, Alex Neil*, John Scott*, Murray Tosh*, Shiona Baird*, Donald Gorrie*, Ms Sandra White*, Mary Scanlon*, Bill Aitken*

S2M-3245# Mrs Nanette Milne: Communication Impairment—That the Parliament notes that there are an estimated 250,000 people in Scotland who have communication impairment; recognises that communication impairment can affect every waking moment of a person’s life and that those affected by communication impairment, by definition, are not easily able to speak up about their needs, and believes that the Scottish Executive should take immediate steps to support quality social action research in order to develop a comprehensive and coherent framework for action on communication impairment in Scotland.Supported by: Brian Adam, Chris Ballance, Ms Rosemary Byrne, Murdo Fraser, Robin Harper, Margaret Mitchell, Eleanor Scott, Alex Neil, John Scott, Murray Tosh, Shiona Baird, Donald Gorrie, Ms Sandra White, Mary Scanlon, Bill Aitken

S2M-3245# Mrs Nanette Milne: Communication Impairment—That the Parliament notes that there are an estimated 250,000 people in Scotland who have communication impairment; recognises that communication impairment can affect every waking moment of a person’s life and that those affected by communication impairment, by definition, are not easily able to speak up about their needs, and believes that the Scottish Executive should take immediate steps to support quality social action research in order to develop a comprehensive and coherent framework for action on communication impairment in Scotland. Supported by: Brian Adam, Chris Ballance, Ms Rosemary Byrne, Murdo Fraser, Robin Harper, Margaret Mitchell, Eleanor Scott, Alex Neil, John Scott, Murray Tosh, Shiona Baird, Donald Gorrie, Ms Sandra White, Mary Scanlon, Bill Aitken, Lord James Douglas-Hamilton, Dr Jean Turner, Mr Adam Ingram, Mr Mark Ruskell, Mr Kenneth Macintosh, Patrick Harvie, Frances Curran, Mark Ballard, Sarah Boyack, Colin Fox, Mike Pringle, Tommy Sheridan, Pauline McNeill, Miss Annabel Goldie, Nicola Sturgeon, Mr Frank McAveety, Ms Wendy Alexander, Mr Andrew Welsh Motions and amendments which have attracted additional support
